member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.Automation.ViewControl`1

summary.para: The base class for WPF view controls which could be registered as Data Templates for some view model automation object, to be applied automatically whenever such object attempts to be presented (see to register with resources automatically).

This class calls a user function to render the content with code. The function is given the bound automation object (whom this data template is presenting) and the lifetime of the binding validity. For the duration of the lifetime, the WPF control is loaded, and the valid automation object is assigned as the data context to this view. The function might be called multiple times for the same view instance (non-overlapping lifetimes) if either the view is unloaded and reloaded, or the automation object is revoked from the data context and reassigned.
This renderer is especially useful when your view has to operate lifetimed entities (e.g. create a complex Windows Forms control, or run an activity while the control is live).
To implement the view renderer, create a derived class specialied with your automation object type as the generic parameter, and do one of the following:
(a) Override the method (do NOT call the base implementation). This is the preferred way if you do not need to dependency-inject Shell components.

(b) Write a public instance method called OnRenderView with a freehand signature. It might take basic parameters of type and (just like ), plus any number of other parameters of Shell component types, which would be injected from the Shell container upon view construction. This would be late-bound-called by name, so prefer overriding if possible.
(c) Override the constructor and pass the rendering function as the lambda parameter. This scenario does not support importing Shell components.

member.typeparam: The type of the automation object for which the data template would be registered. If using the attribute, the Shell would register your data template for this specific type, all its base types, and all its meaningful interfaces.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.Automation.ViewControl`1.RenderCustomMethodWithInjection(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.UI.SrcView.Automation.ViewControl{`0},`0,System.Reflection.MethodInfo,System.Object)
member.summary: Handles the case when the view rendering FN has extra parameters to be dependency injected from the Shell container.

member.summary: Masters the Jet Popup Menu main body presentation. Is a topmost popup window that looks like an MSO-11 v-menu, performs low-level custom layered-window painting to achieve the alpha-channel transparency (non-rectangular form, shadows). member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.Controls.JetPopupMenu.Impl.JetPopupMenuView.GetCaptionLocation(JetBrains.Util.Interop.DpiResolution)
member.summary: Gets the offset of the menu caption from the menu top left corder, which is needed in case you want to position the image right above some object.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.Controls.JetPopupMenu.Impl.JetPopupMenuView.GetCaptionPaddingForDocking
member.summary: If you want to dock the menu with a so that the caption presentation were positioned directly above some area — typically, if you duplicate some visual element into the menu caption so that it appeares as if menu opens out of it — use this padding for the layouter around the which represents the area. The left parameter of the padding is the distance between the caption and the left bound of the menu when the menu opens docked to the right. In this case caption is in the left corner of the menu. The top parameter of the padding is the distance between the caption and the left bound of the menu when the menu opens docked down. In this case caption is above the menu body. The right parameter of the padding is the distance between the caption and the right bound of the menu when the menu opens docked to the left. In this case caption is in the right corner of the menu. The bottom parameter of the padding is the distance between the caption and the bottom bound of the menu when the menu opens docked up. In this case caption is below the menu body. All in all, this should work if you give this as a thickness96 to the ctor. The thickness components are negative to suit the docking.

member.summary: Two-color gradient routine. Fallbacks to flat painting if colors are the same. Does input checks and skips collapsed rects.

Four-color gradient routine, but with only three stops. The color at the center is non-contiguous, the two middle color go into the same coordinate. Fallbacks to three- or two-color or flat painting if some/all colors are the same. Does input checks and skips collapsed rects.

member.summary: Three-color gradient routine. Fallbacks to two-color or flat painting if some/all colors are the same. Does input checks and skips collapsed rects.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer
member.summary: Charms an Avalon HWND Source so that it behaved to per-monitor and dynamically changing DPI.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer.myFirstTimeInitResult
member.summary: Recent WPF versions support dynamic DPI out of the box, but do not activate it by default. Try the manual activation on it.

summary.para: Adds a DPI-charming request for the window. It is OK to call multiple times.

Would force Avalon to switch to the new DPI values for coordinate translation and rendering when the window DPI changes, either due to system DPI change or when moved to a monitor with a different resolution.
Would adjust window physical size when DPI changes to maintain the logical size.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer.CharmAvalonWindowLive(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,System.Windows.Interop.HwndSource,JetBrains.Application.Threading.IThreading,JetBrains.Application.Interop.NativeHook.IWindowsHookManager)

summary.para: Adds a DPI-charming request for the window. It is OK to call multiple times.

Would force Avalon to switch to the new DPI values for coordinate translation and rendering when the window DPI changes, either due to system DPI change or when moved to a monitor with a different resolution.
Would adjust window physical size when DPI changes to maintain the logical size.

member.param: Lifetime for this charming request. If there's more than one request for the same window, it would be charmed for high-DPI until the last lifetime terminates.
The HWND Source of a window to process. Can be either a top-level window or an Element Host. See optional parameters which depend on that.
When points to a top-level window (), might be NULL. For non-top-level windows such as an or , a valid instance of the component must be supplied.
When points to a top-level window (), might be NULL. For non-top-level windows such as an or , a valid instance of the component must be supplied.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer.ForceAvalonWindowDpi(System.Windows.Interop.HwndSource,JetBrains.Util.Interop.DpiResolution)
member.summary: Forces an Avalon window update its DPI.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer.TryTurnOnWpfDpiAwareMode
member.summary: If we're running on a new Windows OS and a new WPF version, turns ON its dynamic DPI awareness and avoids hacking per-window DPI values. Safe to call multiple times.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer.ForceAvalonWindowDpiCore_HealDpiChangeEvent(System.Void*)

summary.para: That's crazy shit. A popup (PopupRoot class as the root visual in the HWND Target, serving the new window for the Popup element in some other visual tree) would sink HwndSource::DpiChanged event and do nothing and suppress any further processing, thus preventing tracking the actual dynamic DPI.
Like this:
All of the dyn dpi processing aborts applying new DPI by this flag.
Kill this event sink on the DpiChanged event in the HWND Source, and everything starts working smoothly.
Do the check before forcing DPI (that would not happen often).

member.returns: Whether we changed anything.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer.AvalonDpiSupportGeneration.Gen1Static
member.summary: The original (or old enough) WPF solution: DPI resolution is acquired once and for all, takes part in coord mapping and painting. We hack into these values to reflect dynamic DPI, and force them reapply (with another set of hacks). This requires per-hwnd-source patching. There is no global hacking.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.CrossFramework.AvalonHwndSourceDpiCharmer.AvalonDpiSupportGeneration.Gen2Dynamic
member.summary: The recent PMv2 upgrade. Supposes DPI is different per window and might change at runtime, tries to track (with partial success) for such changes. This behavior is however not enabled by default but governed by app context switches. We hack the app context switch globally to enable PMv2 dynamic DPI (should be done before creating windows). Per-window hacking still might be required to force the window know its new DPI in some cases when it does not (a non-top-level window reparented into another DPI surrounding). The hack is mild here, just send the new PMv2 Windows Message.

member.summary: This implements our Tooltip Manager tooltips behavior for an Avalon element, for the full area of the element, with dynamic or pull-based behavior for tooltip content.

This implements our Tooltip Manager tooltips behavior for an Avalon element, for the full area of the element, with dynamic or pull-based behavior for tooltip content. The functor which builds the tooltip text on-demand is an async funciton in this case.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.Tooltips.Avalon.AvalonTooltips.WithStaticTooltip``1(``0,JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.Application.UI.UIAutomation.IAutomation,JetBrains.Application.UI.PopupLayout.PopupWindowContextSource,JetBrains.UI.Anchoring2D[])
member.summary: This implements our Tooltip Manager tooltips behavior for an Avalon element, for the full area of the element, with static or retained-state tooltip content. Retained-state means push model rather than pull model: you can change Automation Object's text when you think it should change, regardless of whether tooltip manager asks for tooltip or not. This is less performant than pull-model.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.Behavior.AvalonBehaviorHelpers.AvalonBehaviorStateProperty
member.summary: Behaviors which are based on this helper use the property bag to store a DataFlow copy of the behavior state. The lifetime-driven behavior function binds to it and to the element's loaded state. The transition is as follows: when behavior property value is set, it's copied to the DataFlow property in this bag. When the property is first created, the behavior function is bound to it as follows: when both the property has a non-null value, and the element is loaded into WPF, execute with that lifetime.

summary.para: In WPF, nested focus scopes won't propagate its logical focused control state to the parent focus scope.
Attach this behavior to the root focus scope of a control graph in which nested focus scopes should propagate this state.
Why we need to propagate the state?

(1) Action system toolbars use the logically-focused element to handle commands when focus is not under the scope of the toolbar. For example, tool window toolbar command should apply to the selection in that toolwindow even when focus is in some other tool window.

(2) Restoring focus when window gets activated. Without proper propagation, if focus actually were in a nested focus scope, focus will be restored to the last-focused element in the topmost scope instead of the nested one.

member.remarks: ETW events can also be filtered by level. If the level is set at 0x5, events of all levels, including 0x5 and below (which are events that belong to categories enabled through keywords) are raised. If the level is set at 0x2, only events that belong to level 0x2 and below are raised.

member.summary: These events collect information relating to loading and unloading application domains, assemblies, and modules.
member.remarks: All loader events are raised under the LoaderKeyword (0x8) keyword. The DCStart and the DCEnd events are raised under LoaderRundownKeyword (0x8) with StartRundown/EndRundown enabled.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.SrcView.ProcessExplorer.ETW.ClrEtw.LoaderEvents.ModuleData_V2
member.summary: Event data for Module* events .NET Framework 4.5.

remarks.para: The fields that have "Pdb" in their names can be used by profiling tools to locate PDBs that match the modules that were loaded during the profiling session. The values of these fields correspond to the data written into the IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY_DEBUG sections of the module normally used by debuggers to help locate PDBs that match the loaded modules.

The field names that begin with "ManagedPdb" refer to the managed PDB corresponding to the MSIL module that was generated by the managed compiler (such as the C# or Visual Basic compiler). This PDB uses the managed PDB format, and describes how elements from the original managed source code, such as files, line numbers, and symbol names, map to MSIL elements that are compiled into the MSIL module.

The field names that begin with "NativePdb" refer to the NGen PDB generated by calling NGEN createPDB. This PDB uses the native PDB format, and describes how elements from the original managed source code, such as files, line numbers, and symbol names, map to native elements that are compiled into the NGen module.

The task to run. The given to the task is always free-threaded for both reading and writing, even if .

Allows the owner to attach its UI to the progress of the task. The object given as parameter is always primary-threaded, which means that it fires modifications on the primary thread only. To cancel out the UI or binding, submit to the parameter. Optionally return the window handle, if known already, to keep from disabling when applying the modal state.
The owner-provided progress indicator.
The window focus will be restored to if it was impossible to restore focus to the previous window.

summary.para: Creates a new command corresponding to the action, and registers the command bindings on the view element to which the is applied.
Safe to call multiple times.
Sets up the view element which attaches WPF Command Bindings for Action Manager actions.
To set up the infrastructure for handling Action Manager actions as WPF Commands:
• In the viewmodel, create and expose an instance of .
• On the view element which should define the bindings (one parenting all of the command-using elements), set the behavior's attached dependency property.
• In the viewmodel, get a command for each action you need and expose to the view.
• In the view, use the command as usual (must be within the element with the behavior).
Takes part in attaching WPF Command Bindings for Action Manager actions.
Set this attached dependency property on a view element to fulfil the steps described in docs.

The menu is populated with actions from the group, whose presentation and availability are updated based on the current context.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManagerAvalonEx.CreateActionBarForAvalonControl(JetBrains.Application.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManager,JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,System.String,System.Windows.UIElement)

summary.para: Creates an -driven toolbar to be hosted in Avalon controls with data contexts collected from Avalon controls.

member.param: Creator.
Limiting lifetime for toolbar activities.
ID of the actions group whose actions should be presented as toolbar buttons.

param.name: contextparent
param.para: Outermost control hosting the whole setup with toolbar and payload content controls.
For example, in a tool window that would be your content element. In a window, that would be the window content element. Usually the returned action bar UI element is parented by the context parent.

When keyboard focus is within the context parent, the focused element defines the data context (it's collected by bubbling from the focused element and collecting all the available data rules/constants).

When keyboard focus is not within, the logical focus context is used for gathering data context, which is basically the most recently keyboard-focused element (or, rather, which element would get focused when keyboard focus returns to the window). This allows for keeping the window-local action buttons enabled on the toolbar even when focus is not in the window itself.
To implement this, is set to True on .

member.returns: The toolbar as a UI element.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManagerAvalonEx.CreateActionBarForAvalonControl_AutomaticScoping(JetBrains.Application.UI.ActionSystem.ActionBar.IActionBarManager,JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,System.String)

summary.para: Creates an -driven toolbar to be hosted in Avalon controls with data contexts collected from Avalon controls.
The UI element to collect data rules again is chosen with the : it is the focused element in the focus scope which contains the toolbar itself. Normally, it would be a window, or a toolwindow, etc.

When keyboard focus is actually within this scope, the focused element defines the data context (it's collected by bubbling from the focused element and collecting all the available data rules/constants).

When keyboard focus is not within, the logical focus context is used for gathering data context, which is basically the most recently keyboard-focused element (or, rather, which element would get focused when keyboard focus returns to the window). This allows for keeping the window-local action buttons enabled on the toolbar even when focus is not in the window itself.
If you want to limit the scope, set to True on the appropriate container.

member.param: Creator.
Limiting lifetime for toolbar activities.
ID of the actions group whose actions should be presented as toolbar buttons.
member.returns: The toolbar as a UI element.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Controls.TreeGrid.Virtualization.Tests.VirtualizingCollection`1
member.summary: Specialized list implementation that provides data virtualization. The collection is divided up into pages, and pages are dynamically fetched from the IItemsProvider when required. Stale pages are removed after a configurable period of time. Intended for use with large collections on a network or disk resource that cannot be instantiated locally due to memory consumption or fetch latency.
member.remarks: The IList implmentation is not fully complete, but should be sufficient for use as read only collection data bound to a suitable ItemsControl.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Controls.TreeGrid.TreeGridViewport.SetWin32Focus(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The SetFocus function sets the keyboard focus to the specified window. The window must be attached to the calling thread's message queue. The SetFocus function sends a WM_KILLFOCUS message to the window that loses the keyboard focus and a WM_SETFOCUS message to the window that receives the keyboard focus. It also activates either the window that receives the focus or the parent of the window that receives the focus. If a window is active but does not have the focus, any key pressed will produce the WM_SYSCHAR, WM_SYSKEYDOWN, or WM_SYSKEYUP message. If the VK_MENU key is also pressed, the lParam parameter of the message will have bit 30 set. Otherwise, the messages produced do not have this bit set. By using the AttachThreadInput function, a thread can attach its input processing to another thread. This allows a thread to call SetFocus to set the keyboard focus to a window attached to another thread's message queue.
member.param: [in] Handle to the window that will receive the keyboard input. If this parameter is NULL, keystrokes are ignored.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to the window that previously had the keyboard focus. If the hWnd parameter is invalid or the window is not attached to the calling thread's message queue, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Controls.TreeGrid.TreeGridViewport.GetWin32Focus
member.summary: The GetFocus function retrieves the handle to the window that has the keyboard focus, if the window is attached to the calling thread's message queue.
member.returns: The return value is the handle to the window with the keyboard focus. If the calling thread's message queue does not have an associated window with the keyboard focus, the return value is NULL.

summary.para: Manages the automation providers, as available for our custom controls.
Automation provider implementations require referencing the Avalon assemblies, which we cannot do yet.

When an Avalon-aware DLL is about to query for providers on our controls, it should load the providers DLL and cause them to sign up for this Registry. Subsequently, controls will start returning the providers in response to their .

member.remarks: The default implementation should call into System.Windows.Automation.Provider.AutomationInteropProvider::ReturnRawElementProvider.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Controls.ActionManagerToolBar
member.summary: A UI element for planting the Action Manager Toolbar into the WPF UI. Does not require any components for creating an instance. All of the components and data are databound from the viewmodel.

member.summary: Action bar manager for the toolbar.

member.name: P:JetBrains.UI.Controls.ActionManagerToolBar.ActionGroupId
member.summary: ID of the actions group whose actions should be presented as toolbar buttons.

summary.para: Outermost control hosting the whole setup with toolbar and payload content controls.
For example, in a tool window that would be your content element. In a window, that would be the window content element. Usually the returned action bar UI element is parented by the context parent.

When keyboard focus is within the context parent, the focused element defines the data context (it's collected by bubbling from the focused element and collecting all the available data rules/constants).

When keyboard focus is not within, the logical focus context is used for gathering data context, which is basically the most recently keyboard-focused element (or, rather, which element would get focused when keyboard focus returns to the window). This allows for keeping the window-local action buttons enabled on the toolbar even when focus is not in the window itself.
To implement this, is set to True on .

The case in VS 10 beta 2, where the status bar control itself sits on another thread and causes a marshalling pain for us if operated directly. member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.RenderGdipIntoAvalonImage_GdiBitmap_DIBitmap(System.Windows.Size,JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.AlphaChannel,System.Action{System.Drawing.Graphics})
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.
member.remarks: Thought it could re-use the bits of , but seems like it's not the way it works.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.RenderGdipIntoAvalonImage_GdipBitmap(System.Windows.Size,JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.AlphaChannel,System.Action{System.Drawing.Graphics})
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.
member.remarks: Creates a byte buffer, a GDI+ bitmap right on these bytes, and then an Avalon image off these bytes. Could be easily turned into a to reuse its bytes on subsequent renders of the same size, but in this method if a GDI DC is created off the GDIP DC, then any transparency functions would fail (cannot get the back color it seems), like ClearType or even rectangles with alpha. So we cannot use it as a main method, and thus no use optimizing into a .

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.RenderGdipIntoAvalonImage_GdiBitmap_DIBSection(System.Windows.Size,JetBrains.UI.CrossFramework.AvalonBitmapInterop.AlphaChannel,System.Action{System.Drawing.Graphics})
member.summary: Creates a GDI+ Graphics to render into, and returns the rendering result in a form of an Avalon image.
member.remarks: Creates a GDI bitmap, HDC on it, Graphics on that, and uses the GDI bitmap bytes to create an Avalon image off those. Not quite compatible with because the bits are created by anew each time.

summary.para: A value gets published in the property on all the visual trees which are considered loaded into the real UI.
UI Application Shell tracks all of the visual trees of the real UI, and publishes this into their roots.
All controls, upon being added to these visual trees, can see the value until they are removed.
From this value:
(1) They can infer the lifetime of being loaded and active, with methods like .

NOTE: This has advantage over the older helper which were based on event handling because (a) the event is unreliable and sometimes misses unloading, (b) loading is deferred asynchronously until after the first render, which in case of multiple nested loaded handlers makes a noticeable visual delay, (c) it reloads when reapplying templates, which might lose state even while running.
(2) They can take without retrieving it from component containers or automation models, and with it most of the services needed for running UI.

member.name: P:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.JetAvalonRootToken.Application

summary.para: Creates a lifetime each time the control gets loaded into the tree of loaded elements under some root element marked with our property.
This emulates a deterministic lifetime for WPF elements.
This overload does not take an outer lifetime and is suitable for use in purely-view controls that do not know any external lifetime.
Note that it's not technically guaranteed that the lifetime is ever terminated.

member.summary: Allows to set up handling buttons which either work on click (when mouse goes down, captures, and then goes up within the button), or as a drop-down (when the drop-down opens on mousedown, captures mouse for the drop-down, and then items in the drop-down execute on mouseup just like in a simple menu). The decision is made in the mouse down handler. The handlers are async so that it were possible to take guard/lock within.
member.param: The element on which clicks or opening part of the drop-down is handled.
Logging target.
Mouse down handler. Execute sync if possible, but can go async if cannot enter a transaction right now. See for details.

member.summary: A special version for which is transport-friendly, tailored for sending an async request over protocol and getting a response in the form of which defines further interaction.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.Flags.IsPreviewMouseEvents
member.summary: Whether to handle “Preview—” mouse events rather than regular ones.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.Flags.IsListenToHandledEventsAlways
member.summary: Registers mouse events to handle even in case they have been handled by smb else. No exceptions.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.Flags.IsListenToHandledEventsUnlessCapturedByAlien
member.summary: Registers mouse events to handle even in case they have been handled by smb else. Skip if mouse has been captured by smb who is not our ancestor.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.Flags.IsDontLimitToLeftButton
member.summary: Originally handles the left button only, this can be used to capture all buttons.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownArgs.ChangedButton
member.summary: Tells which button were pressed down (and later clicked).

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownArgs.KeyboardModifiers
member.summary: Keyboard modifiers state at the time of the mouse event.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownArgs.PointInElement
member.summary: The click point in element-relative coords.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownResult.FOnMouseClick
member.summary: After handling mouse down, tells how the corresponding click event should be handled. NULL: not interested in click. The capture and wait for mouse up scaffolding is not initiated. Either you don't want to handle mouse at this time, or maybe you've opened a drop-down and took the capture for it. Non-NULL: interested in getting click. Mouse will be captured and tracked for clicks. The callback will be executed when it's a mouse click. If mouse is released without a valid click, this will be silently dropped without being called.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownResult.IsReportHandled
member.summary: If this result is returned synchronously, then this goes to . If not ready synchronously, then True is assumed, and then the value is ignored.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownResult.ToolArea
member.summary: Optional. Gets the “tool area” containing the given point, NULL means whole Aalon element. A tool area works similarly to a tool area of a classic tooltip, when you have multiple clickable areas within the same element, and we should track mouse leaving not the whole element but a sub-area.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownResult.DontNeedClick
member.summary: Assume handled, but do not need the click.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownResult.Rejected
member.summary: Not handled (and not waiting for click). Can use default value for that.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.MouseDownResult.WaitingForClick(JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.OnMouseClickHandler)
member.summary: Waiting for click, assumes handled.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.States.MouseDownCapturedExpectingClick
member.summary: Mouse down handler completed and said it needs click, mouse is still down, see if it will make a click when the button is released.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.States.MouseDownCapturedAwaitingMouseDownHandlerCompetion
member.summary: Mouse down handler is still running, mouse button still down, we're keeping capture to see if it will be a click.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.States.MouseLostAwaitingMouseDownHandlerCompetion
member.summary: Mouse down handler is still running, our mouse down didn't result in a click and we already know that. No matter what the handler returns, it won't be a click.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.States.GotClickAwaitingMouseDownHandlerCompetion
member.summary: Mouse down handler is still running, our mouse down were released correctly and we got a click. If handler requests a click when completed, the click will be immediately executed.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.MouseDropDownBehavior.States.AwaitingClickHandler
member.summary: Executed the click handler, awaiting async.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.WindowUtil.SetOwnerReliable(System.Windows.Forms.Form,System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window)
member.summary: Sets an owner for the form in a reliable manner. The problem with reliability is that if the owner is not another (ie cannot be used), and form-to-be-owned is not , then the netfx implementation will drop the owner assigned with WinAPI calls and replace it with its own parking window (kinda to prevent it from showing up in the taskbar). This is done after the handle is created and after all of the notifications, so we should wait some more and then reapply the desired parent.

summary.para: Shows the dialog either modally or nonmodally, so that its creation function were guarded, but its execution were not wholy guarded.
Guarding the creation is needed to process modal functions correctly.

Non-guarding the body of execution is required for controls which would be queueing smth guarded to function correctly: if the dialog is guarded throughout its whole lifetime, their activities would not have a chance to execute before it's closed.
If you're calling this method for modal execution, the obviously must not be held at the moment, otherwise it's not possible to fulfil the conditions.

member.param: Limiting lifetime for the whole activity.
Whether to show modally or non-modally.
instance.
Optional. Used to inform VS about modal dialogs.
Dialog creation function.
Optional. Owner window getting function — of: implementation over a WPF , or an implementation over a Win32 HWND, or WinForms window, or NULL to let WPF decide for choosing an owner on its own.
member.returns: If executing modally, the execution result. Otherwise, NULL.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.WindowUtil.ShowFocusCatcher(System.Void*)
member.summary: Shows a window that catches focus and then returns it back immediately, so that the window could process the activation message consistently and place focus on the proper child window. Without that it could happen that focus sits directly on the main window and no child is active.

summary.para: Creates a lifetime each time the control gets loaded into the tree of loaded elements.
This emulates a deterministic lifetime for WPF elements.
This overload does not take an outer lifetime and is suitable for use in purely-view controls that do not know any external lifetime.
Note that it's not technically guaranteed that the lifetime is ever terminated.

summary.para: Creates a new instance of a UI control representing the given Automation Object.
The must be reachable, and a view must be registered for this to work.

Note that you should NOT use this method where content object is expected (like in 's property, or any items). Pass the automation object directly instead, because this method uses the same technique for presenting the content as they would.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Extensions.CreateOrReuseWindow
member.summary: Allows to show popup UI when the user clicks a button. Shows the old window if not closed yet, or creates a new one if not shown yet or already closed.
member.remarks: Usually, in Avalon, the window would be created initially, and show-hidden on user actions without actually destroying and recreating it. In our case there're usually complex bindings running in the window, so we would not like them to be running in the hidden mode.

summary.para: Paints the image on a GDI+ device context.
The size of the painting is expected to the obtained from .
The parameter affects how the image is rasterized, while its screen painting size is solely defined by the .
If you'd like to paint in a nonstandard resolution, e.g. for print, take the Avalon image and rasterize it at a custom resolution.
Paints the image on a GDI+ device context.
The size of the painting is expected to the obtained from .
The parameter affects how the image is rasterized, while its screen painting size is solely defined by the .
If you'd like to paint in a nonstandard resolution, e.g. for print, take the Avalon image and rasterize it at a custom resolution.
Paints the image on a GDI+ device context.
The size of the painting is expected to the obtained from . This size is obeyed directly, without checking the image size and device context resolution.
A view control which works as a DataTemplate for the image source type.
As it is registered with , you can use as content across the product's UI, and it will be presented automatically.

You can also use this control when you need to have fine-grained control over the resulting object and access to its properties. In this case, set the to its property (as would applying a Data Template do), or use the special property which exposes the typed data context (for binding, you should still be using the ).
Exposes the property typed to .
As this object is primarily intended to be used as a data template, it receives the Icon ID in the property. This is a typed facade.
Enables custom snapping offset computation used to increase icon sharpness.
Default value is true .

remarks.para: Custom snapping sometimes conflicts with property, which is the only known reason why one would want to disable it.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Icons.RotatedIconIdViewHelper.GdipBitmapFrames
member.summary: Supports getting individual animation frames as GDI+ bitmaps.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Icons.RotatedIconIdViewHelper.GdipBitmapFrames.myFrameCache96
member.summary: Caches rendered GDI+ frames for icons. Stores the theme to reset the whole cache on theme change. NOTE: don't watch theme changes live to aviod holding icon manager. NOTE: can't think up any reasonable cleanup policy, e.g. weakrefs will never be held because the bitmap object is released just after painting it onscreen. NOTE: Bitmap array size is to have frames in it.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Icons.RotatedIconIdViewHelper.GdipBitmapFrames.myFrameCacheScreenDpi
member.summary: Caches rendered GDI+ frames for icons. Stores the theme to reset the whole cache on theme change. NOTE: don't watch theme changes live to aviod holding icon manager. summary.para: A view control which works as a DataTemplate for the type.
As it is registered with , you can use as content across the product's UI, and it will be presented automatically.

You can also use this control when you need to have fine-grained control over the resulting object and access to its properties. In this case, set the to its property (as would applying a Data Template do), or use the special property which exposes the typed data context (for binding, you should still be using the ).
Exposes the property typed to .
As this object is primarily intended to be used as a data template, it receives the Icon ID in the property. This is a typed facade.
Enables custom snapping offset computation used to increase icon sharpness.
Default value is true.

remarks.para: Custom snapping sometimes conflicts with property, which is the only known reason why one would want to disable it.

member.summary: A data rule finder to traverse thru both worlds (Avalon & WinForms) crossing the boundaries successfully and gathering rules from the whole chain.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.DataContext.GetDataRulesEventArgs.GetDataRulesEvent
member.summary: Fires when the a Data Context is about to be created and looks for s on Avalon UI elements to query for data. This event will fire when you call interface members on , or the method and its siblings. When you sink the event, add your data rules to the list. Do not set to True so that the event could bubble up and collect all of the data providers in the UI tree. Add your data rules to the end, which will make sure the deepest controls take precedence with their most concrete data (unless data rule priority is specifically overridden).

member.summary: Add your data rules to the end of this collection. See documentation for details.

summary.para: Gets the Settings Store context for saving your Options Page settings.
Use this for binding your Options Page settings controls in real time.

In case you need to manually control the context your settings go to (like when they reference solution information and thus have no meaning in the global context), take and operate it directly. In default cases, use this context (which is a context in the same Settings Store).

This context belongs to a Settings Store transaction, so you can freely modify it in Options UI and access this data across pages. The choice of the context depends on the user's settings editing mode: either Smart Save by default, or writing to a specific storage in Advanced mode.

Constructs a popup form controller.
member.param: Defines the lifetime of the popup window. Could be terminated by this class in case the window is closed due to one of the conditions. Bind all of the layouters, window context, and per-popup-window additional resources to this lifetime.
A form to be shown as a popup window.
The owning context for the popup window, which defines when the window should be hidden, and also its layout and size through the layouter.
Flags that identify when to destroy the form.
If True, sets the focus to the popup window.
Specifies the popup window's identity group.
Hooks to enable listening to focus loss in owned windows. If omitted, keeping the form alive while focus is in an owned window is not supported.

summary.para: Does subclassing of the standard WinAPI Status Bar control to attach it to the application's .
Suitable for Visual Studio 7–9 and WinForms standalone applications like DT.

This only implements insering the indicators. Text and emphasis must be handled elsewhere (the reason is that e.g. in VS text is handled with std api while indicators have to be hacked in with subclassing).

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Updates.Xslt.UpdateInfo.RootElementName
member.summary: Root element of the document containing a collection of structures. The children of those element should be of the type, in the XML Serializer sense.

summary.para: Vendor name.
for JetBrains products.
MUST be present.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Updates.Xslt.UpdateInfo.Description
member.summary:
A freehand description of this update.
Optional.

summary.para: The URI from which the installation package could be download. This MUST be the direct download link, not the download HTML page (see for that), as the updater might use it for fetching the installation package.
This URI need not be unique and could point to the same versionless verbatim for any most recent release builds.
Optional.
A BASE64 stream with a serialized to be displayed as an icon for this update.
Optional.

member.name: P:JetBrains.UI.Updates.Xslt.UpdateInfo.Identity
member.summary: Gets the Identity of this instance, which is the .

summary.para: The identity of this update. A link to the online information page for this particular update. MUST be unique among ALL updates — not only those currently available, but also any past and future ones.
MUST be present.
Whether this will be a free update.
If True, then the customer will not have to pay for the product.
If False, then the upgrade MIGHT require a license.
Optional.
If the pricing information is available for the product, specifies the price tag in freehand form.
should be used for free upgrades instead.
Optional.
Full name of the product installed by this update, which includes the product name plus any marketing version. This should not include the company name.
IApplicationDescriptor.ProductFullName for JetBrains products.
will be used if not specified.
Optional.
Short name of the product installed by this update. This should include neither company name nor version number.
IApplicationDescriptor.ProductName for JetBrains products.
MUST be present.
The four-component technical version of the product installed by this update.
MUST be present.

member.summary: A single category of updates that manages the updates for a single product.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Updates.Xslt.UpdatesCategory.CheckForUpdatesInterval
member.summary: Interval between automatic check-for-update attempts.

summary.para: When the updates manager is about to check for updates for this updates category, it collects the information about the local environment. The downloaded filter will be applied to this data. This event allows to replace or alter this information before it's used.
Initially, it's of the type, as gotten from the . You could change it to a serializable object of an arbitrary type.
This event should be advised on each shell startup.

When the updates manager checks for updates, it downloads the XSLT filter from , plus some optional query string parameters that identify the local environment, if needed. This event allows to replace or alter this information before it's used.
Initially, it's gotten from the , called of the result. You could change or replace the key-value pairs dictionary.
This event should be advised on each shell startup.

summary.para: Name of the default category in which the Shell product updates are listed.
Plugins should use categories with different names.
Gets the list of update categories. Each one downloads its own list of available updates, and supports a single product.

The default category, ., is guaranteed to exist. Other categories could be added by plugins, as needed. They're persisted by the manager in the product settings, so normally you do not have to create it each time. However, it could be deleted if the settings are lost, if the updates URI is dead for some time, or if it is not activated for some time.

On startup, you should activate your category with for it to check for new updates and report them, otherwise it will consider the owner to be inactive or unloaded, hibernate, and expire after some time.
To create a new category
Gets the default for the product currently running the Shell.
May be missing if there are no updates for the product.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.TaskBar.TBPFLAG
member.summary: Flags that control the current state of the progress button. Specify only one of the following flags; all states are mutually exclusive of all others.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.TaskBar.TBPFLAG.TBPF_NOPROGRESS
member.summary: Stops displaying progress and returns the button to its normal state. Call the method with this flag to dismiss the progress bar when the operation is complete or canceled.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.TaskBar.TBPFLAG.TBPF_INDETERMINATE
member.summary: The progress indicator does not grow in size, but cycles repeatedly along the length of the taskbar button. This indicates activity without specifying what proportion of the progress is complete. Progress is taking place, but there is no prediction as to how long the operation will take.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.TaskBar.TBPFLAG.TBPF_NORMAL
member.summary: The progress indicator grows in size from left to right in proportion to the estimated amount of the operation completed. This is a determinate progress indicator; a prediction is being made as to the duration of the operation.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.TaskBar.TBPFLAG.TBPF_ERROR
member.summary: The progress indicator turns red to show that an error has occurred in one of the windows that is broadcasting progress. This is a determinate state. If the progress indicator is in the indeterminate state, it switches to a red determinate display of a generic percentage not indicative of actual progress.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.TaskBar.TBPFLAG.TBPF_PAUSED
member.summary: The progress indicator turns yellow to show that progress is currently stopped in one of the windows but can be resumed by the user. No error condition exists and nothing is preventing the progress from continuing. This is a determinate state. If the progress indicator is in the indeterminate state, it switches to a yellow determinate display of a generic percentage not indicative of actual progress.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.TaskBar.THUMBBUTTON.THBN_CLICKED
member.summary: WPARAM value for a THUMBBUTTON being clicked.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Utils.ForceResetProcessWideAwareness.ChildControlParented
member.summary: A helper which ensures the child control is created parented from the beginning. This is critical for a reset because creating with an incompatible parent would cause a reset while an attempt to SetParent would just fail on newer Win10.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Utils.ModelViewSingleConnectionTracker`2
member.summary: When a view control connects to an automation object, sometimes the automation object is not supposed to serve multiple connections at once. (NOTE this class speaks of models rather than automation objects (viewmodels) because you might want to track underlying models rather than viewmodels if they're single-view-only) This class allows to get a live flag to track when you're the best view for the model and can serve the exclusive view for it. Possible cases: • You're the one and only view, everything is OK. • The automation object with your model has been rendered in more than one place. Only one of them will be elected as the "best view" and will be allowed to connect. This status is tracked live, i.e. when the current best view closes, some other is elected. • The automation object is used properly, but it's being moved to another content presenter, or its content presenter is being moved to another visual tree. The sequencing of events due to the visual tree works or operations reordering due to a reentrancy guard might happen so that for a short period of time multiple views exist for the same automation object. This helper makes sure the transition does not violate single-use rule. This is the main use case for which it exists.
member.typeparam: A viewmodel or a model under it, or even a key. A reference or a value type.
The view or some characteristic part of it.

member.summary: Fixes the strategy for picking the best view. Assume last, reason: if two views have been created intentionally for an object for which it is not allowed, this does not matter; if it's a transitional state (e.g. reconnecting to a new view after moving the control around, and we got new view creation event BEFORE the old view destruction event), then to improve presentation we connect to the new view immediately.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Utils.SingleItemByMultipleRequests`2
member.summary: When there are multiple requests for the same thing (identified by ) from several parties, factors the instance on-demand for the duration while at least one request is present. If you do not have a request key, then it could be achieved by a simple CollectionEvents(of object).CreateIsNotEmpty().WhenTrue(), but here it would be multiple collection events per each key value, and they have to be cleaned up. This class basically does a OneToSetEvents(Of TKey,object) for this specific case.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Utils.SingleItemByMultipleRequests`2.JoinOrCreate(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,`0)
member.summary: Either creates a new (if there are no outstanding requests for the same ), or returns an existing item for that and makes sure it is not destroyed until your ends.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Utils.SingleItemByMultipleRequests`2.TryGet(`0,`1@)
member.summary: Like , but only peeks into the current value, does not join (i.e. does not ensure the item is kept alive by the caller's lifetime) not create (would return NULL). Note that this does NOT provide any synchronization, do it externally if needed. If you want built-in sync, it should be something like calling with a temporary lifetime.
member.param: Key by which items are created.
Returns the item if present at the moment of the query, or NULL if not, see return value.
member.returns: Whether the item were available — at the moment of the call.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Utils.WinFormsControlDpiTracker
member.summary: Tracks LIVE resolution of a Windows Forms control (which MUST NOT be a form). A form is tracked separately from a control because it requires much less components to do so, and might be a critical options for some code locations. Only updates it offstack, i.e. if in the middle of some layout/render code it suddenly changes smth (e.g. parenting or coordinates) so that system DPI for this control changes, lets the rest of the operation get the same consistent DPI values. Next time layout/render is called, would then have the new value. Getting the current resolution (non-live) also returns this value.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.Utils.DpiUtil
member.summary: The DPI Utility class which knows about the dynamic DPI.

summary.para: The resolution in which the system has booted (or logged in the current session). On newer Windows, this might be fixed per application start time rather than logon time.
If not , then all of the DPI values in the system will be equal to this.
Since DPI is per-window, you should use DpiResolutions::From…() whenever possible. DPI can change in time, so use the live versions and apply changes.
If you do not know the window/control you'd be used in, or you are currently not attached to any visual, use as the safest fallback.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Utils.DpiUtil.DpiMightHaveChanged
member.summary: Fires when any of the system DPI-related settings might have changed. For a window, this does not cover all cases because the window could have been moved to another display.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Utils.DpiUtil.FallbackDpi
member.summary: Gives _some_ DPI value which you should use when you cannot get the real DPI of the location. This might happen if your control has not been placed yet, or you are rendering without connection to the real UI, or if you are waiting to get the real DPI. The point is that you must use _some_ value anyway, and better it match the intended DPI otherwise there will be a mismatch or a resize animation. This should give the DPI of the application main window, if known, otherwise the primary display DPI.

member.name: F:JetBrains.UI.Utils.DpiUtil.HighestResolutionScreenDpi

Of all the current screen DPIs, the highest one.
If you do not know the window/control you'd be used in, or you are currently not attached to any visual, use as the safest fallback.
If not , then same as .

Of all the current screen DPIs, the lowest one.

summary.para: Current DPI of the primary monitor.

Since DPI is per-window, you should use DpiResolutions::From…() whenever possible. DPI can change in time, so use the live versions and apply changes.
If you do not know the window/control you'd be used in, or you are currently not attached to any visual, use as the safest fallback.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Utils.DpiUtil.GetSystemDpiForOurProcess
member.summary: Originally, that were the boot time system DPI (hence ). Later on, Windows 10 April 2018 Update added a feature that it snapshots the primary display DPI at the moment a process is started as its per-process system DPI. And added the API. Theoretically, it's still static in the process lifetime, and should do. But hell knows their ideas. So let's call the function for sure (if OS is new enough).

member.summary: For a top-level window, tracks LIVE its DPI resolution. A top-level window receives a DPI change message from the OS, and does not require the Windows Hook Manager for tracking. Also it receives the suggested window bounds change message, see returned class. Must not pass a child window in here.

member.summary: Gets the system-wide boot-time (or logon-time) screen DPI which does not reflect dynamic and per-monitor DPI changes.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Wpf.View.RenderGuarded(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,System.Nullable{JetBrains.Lifetimes.OuterLifetime},JetBrains.Application.Threading.IThreading,System.Func{JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,System.Windows.UIElement})
member.summary: Wraps a lifetimed renderer function which requires guarded execution and guarded lifetime termination. The latter needs to create a new lifetime and schedule its termination correctly.
member.param: The original non-guarded lifetime originally available to you (e.g. from WhenLoaded, ViewControl, etc).

Optional, but recommended. A guarded (!) lifetime of some component related to your implementation. The original unguarded lifetime might terminate _later_ than the components you're using for your view, and guarded termination execution initiated by it will execute even later. The guarded lifetime is nested within this one, if provided, to guarantee your view does not live for too long.
Guards and scheduling.
The renderer function, gets the guarded lifetime.
member.returns: The element from the renderer.

summary.para: Exposes the central Resource Dictionary whch should be available to every piece of WPF UI within the platform-based product.
Some of the UI controls rely on theming colors, icons, automation object views and other resources which must be externally applied to them thru this dictionary.
If you would like to publish a resource to make it universally available:
(1) Look for an existing subsystem for registering your kind of resources, such as an icon or a color. Thus subsystem will expose them for you through this dictionary.
(2) If this is a new kind of resources, add a new to the collection of .

If you're authoring a new top-level WPF control (Window, Visual Studio Tool Window integration, etc), make sure to publish this dictionary on your WPF controls tree root. See for an MVVM helper for that.

member.summary: Tells the control the details about the new layout applied to it by the controlling entity in conjunction with some . Typically, the control need not apply the given size and location because that should be done by the controlling entity. The control may change its presentation in response to the layouting details, for example, whether it's attached to the top or the bottom of the anchoring rect.
member.param: The layouting details.

member.name: P:JetBrains.UI.Validation.WindowlessControlView.AutoActivate
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the control should be activated initially when it's shown. The typical implementation for a form is to return a negative of this value from the override.

member.name: P:JetBrains.UI.Validation.WindowlessControlView.WantsResize
member.summary: Fires when the control would like to be reasked of its desired size.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.Validation.WindowlessControlView.GetTooltip(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalPoint)
member.summary: Called by tooltip manager, if the tooltip is to be displayed
member.param: Point in control's coordinates
member.returns: , or Null if no tooltip should be displayed.

member.name: T:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.MainWindowLayouter
member.summary: Layouts a window by placing it relatively to the main window.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.MainWindowLayouter.CreateCenteredCorner(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.Application.StdApplicationUI.IMainWindow,JetBrains.Application.Interop.NativeHook.IWindowsHookManager)
member.summary: Creates a layouter that layouts the content by its top-left corner at approximately the center of the main window. When the content size changes, its left-top corner won't move. Unlike , it's not truely centered, but the title of your content won't jump when it resizes.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.MainWindowLayouter.CreateCenteredCornerDescriptor(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.Application.StdApplicationUI.IMainWindow,JetBrains.Application.Interop.NativeHook.IWindowsHookManager)
member.summary: Creates a description of layouter that layouts the content by its top-left corner at approximately the center of the main window. When the content size changes, its left-top corner won't move. Unlike , it's not truely centered, but the title of your content won't jump when it resizes.

member.name: M:JetBrains.UI.WindowManagement.MainWindowLayouter.CreateCenteredMiddle(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.Application.StdApplicationUI.IMainWindow,JetBrains.Application.Interop.NativeHook.IWindowsHookManager)
member.summary: Creates a layouter that places the content in the center of the main window. When the content size changes, it remains centered. Unlike , this layouter won't fix the content's title in place, but at each moment the content will be truely centered in the main window.

para.para: Autogenerated identifier classes and identifier objects to Themed Icons registered with .
Identifier classes should be used in attributes, XAML, or generic parameters. Where an value is expected, use the identifier object in the Id field of the identifier class.

remarks.para: This code was compile-time generated to support Themed Icons in the JetBrains application.

It has two primary goals: load the icons of this assembly to be registered with so that they were WPF-accessible and theme-sensitive; and emit early-bound accessors for referencing icons in codebehind in a compile-time-validated manner.
For performance reasons, the icons are not individually exposed with application resources. There is a custom markup extension to bind an image source in markup.
To use an icon from XAML, set an property to the markup extension, which takes an icon identifier class (nested in class) as a parameter.
Example:
Sometimes you have to reference an icon from a type attriute when you're defining objects in code. Typical examples are Options pages and Tool Windows.

To avoid the use of string IDs which are not validated very well, we've emitted identifier classes to be used with typeof() expression, one per each icon. Use the attribute overload which takes a for an image, and choose your icon class from nested classes in the class.
Example:
In codebehind, we have two distinct tasks: (a) specify some icon in the APIs and (b) render icon images onscreen.

On the APIs stage you should only manipulate icon identifier objects (of type , statically defined in in Id fields). Icon identifier classes (nested in ) should be turned into icon identifier objects as early as possible. Rendering is about getting an to assign to WPF, or to use with GDI+ / Windows Forms.

You should turn an identifier object into a rendered image as late as possible. The identifier is static and lightweight and does not depend on the current theme, while the image is themed and has to be loaded or generated/rasterized. You need an instance to get the image out of an icon identifier object. Once you got the image, you should take care to change it with theme changes — either by using a live image property, or by listening to the theme change event. See and its extensions for the related facilities.
Example:
remarks.code: // Getting IconId identifier object to use with APIs IconId iconid = ExtensionManagerThemedIcons.Trinity.Id;
// Getting IconId out of an Icon Identifier Class type IconId iconid = new JetBrains.Application.Icons.CompiledIconsCs.CompiledIconCsId(typeof(ExtensionManagerThemedIcons.Trinity));
// Getting image for screen rendering by IconId themediconmanager.Icons[icnoid]
// Getting image for screen rendering by Icon Identifier Class themediconmanager.GetIcon<ExtensionManagerThemedIcons.Trinity>()
remarks.para: This code was generated by a pre-compile build task from a set of input files which are XAML files adhering to a certain convention, as convenient for exporting them from the Illustrator workspace, plus separate PNG files with raster icons. In the projects, these files are designated with ThemedIconsXamlV3 and ThemedIconPng build actions and do not themselves get into the output assembly. All of such files are processed, vector images for different themes of the same icon are split and combined into the single list of icons in this assembly. This list is then written into the genearted XAML file (compiled into BAML within assembly), and serves as the source for this generated code.
